subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... [...] I entirely agree that TestCases are (despite the name) intended to represent fixtures, and that mindlessly creating one TestCase per class under test
messageBody:
Quoth Dave Astels <dave@...>:
> TestCases and Classes being tested should have only coincedental
> correspondance. A TestCase is the embodiment of a *fixture*... a
> specific context in which tests are run. As such it should contain
> only those tests (i.e. test methods) which run in the context of the
> fixture that the TestCase embodies.
[...]

I entirely agree that TestCases are (despite the name) intended to
represent fixtures, and that mindlessly creating one TestCase per
class under test is a Bad Thing. Your example in a subsequent
post of separate TestCases for a list implementation illustrates
the point quite nicely.

However, I think there are cases in which it is sensible to have
one TestCase for one class. For example, suppose we have a
Comparator which sorts Integers lexicographically according to
their written-out forms in English. The class has no internal
state; all instances are equivalent.

In such a case, it seems to me not unreasonable to have a series
of methods, say, one to test that 8 < 7, one to test that 2 > 3,
and so forth, all in the same TestCase. I can't think of a set of
tests of such a class which merit a separate fixture.

We might take the view that, when a TestCase is closely tied to a
single class this way, the fixture under test consists simply of
the class itself (rather than an instance with some specific
state). If there is nothing else in common among the test
methods, it is not unreasonable to leave them all in the same
TestCase, rather than, say, putting each in its own TestCase.
